Effect of the proportion between PET and EG The experiments shown in Figure 2 were carried out to eva luate the relationship between the PET: EG ratio (m / m) and the results of conversion and yield. The other variables (time 30 min and 5% catalyst) were kept constant. In comparison with the standard experiment, the 50% reduction in the amount of EG (exper iment 6) caused a decrease in yield, but the PET conversion was not affected. The 50% increase in the amount of EG (experiment 7), on the other hand, promoted a decrease in BHET yield and PET conversion. Liu et al. (2018) studied glycolysis using different eutectic solvents and experimental conditions. In their work, a lower glycolysis yield was also verified using PET: EG ratios (m / m) lesser than 1: 4, with a significant decrease in yield in proportions less than 1: 3 (m / m). According to Liu et al. (2018) this is because the glycolysis reaction occurs on the PET surface, therefore the amount of EG needs to be sufficient to completely moisten the PET granules. Regarding the increase in the amount of EG, Liu et al. (2018) did not observe a decrease in con version and yield. However, Chen et al. (2012) studied the effect of different proportions between PET and EG (1:3, 1:5 and 1:7 (m/m)) on glycolysis, using 2% zinc acetate as a catalyst, and observed that the experiments of glycolysis containing more ethyl ene glycol took longer to reach equilibrium, requiring more time to reach the maximum yield relative to the experimental
condition. Therefore, it is possible that experiment 7 has not reached equilibrium in 30 minutes of reaction and requires more time to completely consume PET.
Figure 2 Effect of the proportion between PET and EG. The proportion PET:EG in experiment 6, experiment standard and experiment 7 is equal 1:2, 1:4 and 1:6 respectively

Effect of catalyst quantity and reaction time The experimen ts shown in Figure 3 were intended to verify whether the increase in reaction time would enable a greater BHET yield and also the possibility of reducing the amount of catalyst. Experiment 1 has the same conditions as the standard, but with longer reaction time. Unlike expected, the BHET yield was lower. A reverse reaction of glycolysis may have occurred, again forming BHET dimers, as shown in figure 21 (Liu et al., 2018; Raheem et al., 2018; Katoch et al., 2012, Imham et al., 2010). To be sure about the re verse reaction it will be necessary to repeat experiment 1 and, if the result remains, also test a longer reaction time to see if the yield reduction behavior is maintained. Experiments 2 and 3 were carried out with 50% less catalyst compared to the standa rd experiment, differing in the 100% 100% Conversion (%) Yield (%)

reaction time (30min and 1h respectively). Experiment 3 had better performance than standard experiments and 2, however, considering the positive error they were similar. Therefore, it is possible to conclude that the decrea se in the amount of catalyst did not negatively affect the results. Wang et al. (2015) tested the effect of the concentration of eutectic catalysts on the conversion and selectivity of glycolysis and obtained 100% yield from 2.5% catalyst and the best yiel d results were obtained between 2.5 and 5% catalyst, the amount of 5% being slightly better in selectivity. Liu et al. (2018) also tested eutectic catalysts in glycolysis, obtaining better conversion and selectivity results from 2.5% catalyst. Therefore, t he experiments carried out in this work are following the data observed in the literature.

3.4 Analysis of BHET

The results obtained from DSC, 1H-NMR, and 13C-NMR, the main product was analyzed by DSC 1H and 13C-NMR are available in the supplementary material (Figures S1, S2, and S3 respectively). The purity achieved was between 98 and 99.3%.
3.5 Enzymatic hydrolysi s of BHET

The monomer BHET has a similarity with the structure of the PET unit and because of this it has been used for the study of hydrolysis of PET. Hantani et al. (2018) used BHET to measure the hydrolytic activity of Saccharomonospora viridis mutant c utinase (Cut190), obtaining only MHET as the final product. Joo et al. (2018) and Yoshida et al. (2016) used BHET as a substrate to measure the hydrolytic activity of IsPETase, being generated as a 42% 85% 97% 100% 100% 100% Time (min) Conversion (%) Yield (%)

hydrolysis product only MHET. Carniel et al. (2017) also u sed BHET as a substrate to test 10 commercial enzymes, obtaining positive results of BHET biodegradation mainly with Humicola insolens (HiC) cutinase and Candida antarctica lipase B, however, only CaLB was able to produce a high concentration of TPA (99.4% conversion), while HiC produced mostly MHET. Due to the results of the high conversion of BHET to TPA obtained by Carniel et al. (2017), CaLB was chosen for the hydrolysis experiments in this work.

The results of BHET, MHET, and TPA quantification, obtai ned by HPLC analysis, are shown in table 15. The sample aliquots were diluted 200 times in HPLC grade methanol. Statistical analyzes using a DCCR experimental design were performed assuming a 95% confidence interval.

Looking at the response surface graph in Figure 7 (A), it is possible to verify that the best conversion results are achieved at the lowest temperatures and pHs o f the experimental design. The increase in enzymatic load, seen in Figure 7 (C), gives a positive effect on conversion, with the temperature set at 55 ° C, however when the temperature of 47 ° C is set the amount of enzyme seems to be less relevant (Figure 7 (C) and (D)). In Figure 7 (B), which studies the combined effects of temperature and enzyme concentration, the amount of enzyme also appears to be less important. In the Pareto graph, it is possible to observe that the terms of greatest statistical impo rtance are those related to temperature, followed by terms related to pH, so that when the temperature is set within the optimum range (Figure 7 (D)), the term related to the enzyme becomes less important. Although the enzyme seems to have little importanc e in some analyzes of surface graphs, the degradation of BHET in TPA and MHET occurs due to the presence of the enzyme, especially if we consider that the optimal experimental conditions occur at mild temperatures and pHs, which reduces the possibility of hydrolysis by temperature increase. Therefore, we can interpret that when the experiment is in the optimum temperature and pH range, it is possible to obtain good results using the minimum amount of enzyme proposed. The best result shown in table 15 was fr om experiment 9 (92% conversion), done with the lowest temperature of the experimental design (47 °C), being following the conclusions of the statistical analyzes. The desirability function (Figure 8) was used to find out exactly the conditions that lead t o the maximum conversion, resulting in a temperature of 47 ° C, pH between 5.3 and 6.2 and minimum enzyme load
(0.00136 g protein/ g BHET), since the increase in the amount of enzyme did not benefit in the conversion.

The results were promising since the best results were achieved in the mildest temp eratures of the planning, allowing less energy expenditure and also less enzyme expenditure. It was not expected that the best results would be achieved at lower temperatures, as BHET's solubility is impaired at lower temperatures, and insoluble compounds have limited diffusion (Pilati et al., 1996). Carniel et al. (2016) obtained a 99.4% yield in TPA, using the same concentration of BHET, at a temperature of 37 °C. Another experimental planning can be done considering milder conditions of temperature and p H, to try to increase the conversion and also to verify the relation between the enzymatic efficiency in the conversion of BHET to TPA and the limitations of the mass transfer, since in the lower temperatures the BHET will not be soluble. It is also possib le to observe in Table 4 that BHET was almost completely consumed in most experiments, except in experiment 5, which is probably an outlier. 6. Conclusion

Chemical pretreatment may be able to assist enzymatic performance in the degradation of high-crystalline PET. In this work, we c hose to choose a chemical pre -treatment method, glycolysis, using urea -based solvents and metal salts. It was possible to achieve a BHET yield of almost 70% in just 20 minutes, more economically than if using pure metallic salt, since urea has a lower cost than zinc acetate. The BHET generated in glycolysis was subsequently hydrolyzed by CaLB, obtaining 92% conversion of BHET to TPA, using little enzyme and mild reaction conditions.

Therefore, the experiments were successful since it was possible to generat e TPA with high yield from PET with high crystallinity. Better results of converting BHET to TPA can be achieved, as the optimum region is located at the lower extremities of pH and temperature of the planning, it is not possible to know if it is possible to obtain higher conversions using temperatures and pHs lower than those of the planning. A new experimental design can be made, choosing lower temperatures and pHs, for example, temperature from 30 to 40 ° C and pH from 5 to 7 ° C
